LEAGUE OF nations committee on Amendments to the Covenant.Note by the Secretary- General.The following letter from Mr. Charles J. Doherty, with its enclosures certain memoranda in support of the proposal of the Canadian Delegation at the Assembly to strike out Article 10 of the Covenant, is submitted for the consideration of the Committee on Amendments to the Covenant, and is circulated for the information of the Members of the League.Ottawa, June ist, 1921Sir,I have the honomr to transmit herewith certain memoranda in support of the motion of the Canad an Delegation at the last Assembly of the League of Nations to eliminate Article 10 from the Covenant ot the League. I have the honour to be, Sir,Your obedient Servant,(Signed) CHARLES J. DOHERTY-The Right Honourable Arthur J. Balfour, P.C., President of the Commission on Proposed Amendments to the Covenant of the League of Nations, London,S. d. N. D. 450.7/21, Imp. Kundig. MEMOIRE RELATIF A L AMENDEMENT DU CANADA TENDANT A SUPPRIMER LARTICLE 10 DU PACTE DE LA societe des NATIONS.En presentant a la Premiere Assemblee de la Societe des Nations une propo-sition tendant a supprimer du Pacte 1 "article io, la Delegation canadienne n'a fait que se conformer a 1'attitude prise par le Gouvernement canadien des le debut, avant meme que le Pacte fut adopte. A 1'epoque oil la Commission de la Societe des Nations a la Conference de la Paix etudiait les termes du Pacte, les delegues canadiens de la Conference ont, au nom de leur Gouvernement, presente des objec-tions a 1'article io. Le Gouvernement canadien a finalement accepte le Pacte tel qu'il a ete incorpore au Traite de Paix, car il a pense que 1'article 26 serait proba-blement utilise par la Societe pour amender et perfectionner 1'instrument du Pacte.Sir Robert Borden, alors Premier Ministre du Canada, et M. C. J. Doherty Ministre de la Justice, tous deux membres de la Delegation du Canada a la Confe-rence de la Paix, ont redige et presente a la Conference plusieurs memoires expli-quant le point de. vue du, Canada. Copies de ces memoires figurent en annexes, a titre de renseignement, pour la Commission chargee d'etudier les projets d'amende-ments au Pacte. Copie du proces-verbal de la seance du Conseil prive du 16 avril 1919 (P. C. 813) adopte par le Gouvemejment canadien et confirmant 1'attitude prise par ses delegues, figure egalement dans 1'annexe.Ni le temps qui s'est ecoule, ni les evenements qui se sont produits n'ont fait perdre de leur force, nous le croyons, aux arguments exposes dans ces memoires. Au contraire, cette force s'est trouvee accrue par les consequences memes qu'a amenees 1'insertion dans le Pacte, de 1'article 10. Cet article, en effet, a contribue pour une large part, a priver la Societe de 1'avantage de compter parmi ses Membres 1'un des plus grands Etats du monde, celui-la meme que Ton croyait etre le plus en faveur de cet article.A F Assemblee de la Societe des Nations, nous avons eu un autre exemple des consequences regrettables entrainees par 1'article 10; car c'est principalement a cause de cet article qu'on n'a pu accueillir les demandes d'admission d'Etats, dont les titres n'etaient pas serieusement discutes, mais dont la position meme de leurs territoires respectifs est si precaire que les Etats Membres de la Societe ont pense qu'ils ne pouvaient pas, en les admettant parmi eux, assumer a leur egard les lourdes obligations que cet article faisait peser sur eux.Cest avec confiance que les delegues du Canada presentent leur motion ten-dant a supprimer cet article, dont ils croient avoir prouve qu'il pretait aux plus serieuses critiques.Les evenements ont demontre qu'il est des plus prejudiciables aux interets les plus eleves de la Societe. Sans lui, le Pacte serait un instrument tout aussi effi-cace, sinon plus, pour le maintien de la paix.Presente respectueusement au nom du Canada et des delegues du Canada a I/jAlSsctiiIdIgg(Signe) CHARLES J. DOHERTY.[Traduction.]P. C. 813.Copie certifide conforme d'un rapport du ComiU du Conseil prive1, approuvdpar S. E. le Gouverneur giniral, le 16 avril 1919.Le Comite du Conseil prive a ete saisi d'un rapport date du 12 avril 1919, emanant du Secretaire d'Etat des Affaires etrangeres en fonctions, a qui avait ete transmise une communication du Secretaire d'Etat des Colonies (Dominions, n0 144), en date du 28 fevrier 1919, accompagnee d'un exemplaire du Pacte de la Societe des Nations. Le rapport du Secretaire des Affaires Etrangeres soumettait un memoire sur le Pacte, en date du 13 mars, prepare par le Premier Ministre du Canada, et proposant certains amendements au Pacte.Le Ministre se interalliees aux suggestions contenues dans le memoire, et propose en MEMORANDUM RESPECTING THE CANADIAN AMENDMENT TO STRIKE OUT ARTICLE ro OF THE COVENANT OF THE LEAGUE OF NATIONS.Tn presenting at the First Assembly of the League of Nations a proposal that Article 10 should be eliminated from the Covenant, the Canadian Delegation was simply acting in conformity with the attitude taken by the Canadian Government at the outset and before the Covenant was adopted. When the terms of the Covenant were being considered by the League of Nations Commission at the Paris Peace Conference, the Canadian representatives at the Conference objected on behalf of their Government to the inclusion of Article 10. The Canadian Government ulti-mately accepted the Covenant as it stood in the Treaty of. Peace, since it was felt that Article 26 would in all likelihood be invoked later by the League to amend and perfect the instrument.Memoranda in support of the Canadian position were prepared and submitted at the Peace Conference by the Right Honourable Sir Robert Borden, the then Prime Minister, and by the Right Honourable C. J. Doherty, Minister of Justice, members of the Canadian Delegation at the Conference. Copies of these memoranda are annexed hereto for the information of the Committee dealing with proposed amend-ments to the Covenant. A copy of the Minute of Privy Council of April 16th, 1919 (P.C. 813) adopted by the Canadian Government confirming the position so taken is also annexed hereto.The considerations set forth in these memoranda have, it is confidently submitted, lost nothing of their force by the lapse of time or by reason of events that have taken place since they were written. On the contrary, that force has been added to by the consequences that the insertion of Article 10 in the Covenant has brought about. That Article has played a very large part in depriving the League of the great ad-vantage of counting among its Members one of the greatest States of the world, the very State which was believed to be most anxious for its insertion.At the Assembly of the League, we had another instance of a regrettable conse-quence of the existence of this Article, in the fact that it afforded the principal ground for excluding from membership in the League, States applying for such membership whose qualifications were not seriously disputed but whose tenure of their respective territory was so precarious that the Members States felt that they could not, by ad-mitting them, assume in their regard the onerous obligations of this Article.The Canadian representatives submit with confidence their motion for the elimi-nation of this Article, which they believe they have shown to be open to most serious objection.Events have demonstrated it to be most detrimental to the best interests of the League.Without it the Covenant will be at least as effective, if not indeed a more effec-tive instrument, for the maintenance of peace.Respectfully submitted on behalf of Canada and the Canadian delegates to the Assembly.(Signed) CHARLES J. G. 813.Certified copy of a Report of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor-General on April i6th, 1919.The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated April 12th, 1919, from the Acting Secretary of-State for External Affairs, to who 11 was referred a despatch from the Right Honourable the Secretary of State for the Co-lonies, Dominions No. 144, dated February 28th, 1919, with copy of the draft League of Nations Covenant, submitting a copy of a memorandum on this Covenant, dated March 13th, 1919, prepared by the Prime Minister of Canada, in which certain ainend-ments in the Covenant are suggested. -The Minister concurs in these suggestions and submits that Article 8 of the outre que 1'article 8 fasse 1'objet d'un nouvel amendement, portant interdiction de la fabrication d'armes et de munitions de guerre par 1'industrie privee, et stipulated-lant cgalement quc les armes et munitions de guerre seraient, a 1'avenir, fabriquecs uniquement par les gouvernements interesses.Les Conseillers de Votre Excellence desirent exprimer leur approbation des principes enonces clans le Pacte, sous reserve des amendements proposes clans le Memoire du Premier Ministre, et de ramendement additionnel presente ci-joint. II est bien entendu cependant que tous les signataires du Pacte reconnaissent que:i. Le droit de chaque nation de regler et de surveiller la composition de sa population, en restreignant 1'immigration, reste enticr, et cette sur-veillance est reconnue comme constituant unc question cVordre purement inte-rieur dans laquelle la Societe des Nations n'a pas a intervenir;2. Ce Pacte n'affecte en rien la liberte financicre du Canada, ni son droit d'etablir ou cle reglementer ses propres tarifs.Le Comite du Conseil prive propose, sur la recommandation du Secretaire cVEtat des Affaires Etrangeres en fonctions, qu'un exemplaire du present rapport soit aclresse au Premier Ministre.Nous avons 1'honneur cle vous soumettre respectueusement ce qui precede.(Signi) RODOLPHE BOUDREAU, Greffier du Conseil prive.ARTICLE io DU PACTE. - GARANTIE DE DINTEGRITE TERRITORIALE DE TOUS LES MEMBRES DE LA SOCIETE . CONTRE TOUTE AGRESSION EXTERIEURE,Memoire par le Tres Honorable C. J. Doherty.Cet article prete, a mon avis, a de tres graves objections, d'une fagon generale d'abord, et ensuite au point cle vue particulier des pays qui se trouvent dans la situa-tion et le degre de developpement du Canada.On ne saurait mettre en doute la gravite des obligations qu'il impose aux Etats parties a la Convention. II fait de la Societe, selon 1'expression du Times, ((Une Societe de garantie mutuelle a responsabilite illimitee)).a) Objections d'un caractere gendral. Cette clause fait de chacun des Etats signataires de la Convention, le garant des territoires de tous les Membres de la Societe, non seulement de ceux qu'ils peuvent acquerir en execution des clauses du Traite de Paix, mais aussi de tous ceux qu'ils ont en leur possession, quelle que soit 1'epoque a laquelle ils les ont acquis ou la maniere dont ils les ont acquis.En ce qui concerne les territoires dont la possession a ete attribute a un Etat particulier, en vertu du Traite de Paix, il semble legitime que les Etats qui ont ete parties au reglement et qui ont fait cette attribution, en garantissent la possession au beneficiaire, s'ils considerent qu'il est cle leur devoir ou de leur interet de le faire.Mais, pourquoi toutes les nations, d'une fagon generale, meme si elles n'ont pas participe au reglement des revcndications contestees sur certains territoires, devraient-elles, comme condition cle leur admission dans la Societe, s'engager a accor-der leur protection a 1'Etat beneficiaire ? engagement qui peut jeter ceux qui Pont pris dans toutes les horreurs de guerres oil elles n'ont aucun interet, afin de faire respecter des decisions auxquelles elles n'ont point participe, et pour lesquelles elles n'ont pas de responsabilite.Lorsqu'on arrive a examiner les consequences de 1'article, en ce qui concerne des possessions territoriales existantes, c'est-a-dire les possessions de toutes les puissances belligerantes victorieuses et des nations neutres, telles qu'elles existaient a 1'epoque de la reunion de la Conference de la Paix, possessions dont la delimi-tation et 1'exam en n'etaient en aucune maniere du ressort de la Conerence cle la Paix, il semble que les objections soient encore plus serieuses.Un engagement de cette nature a 1'egard desdits territoires presuppose, de la part de ceux qui Pont pris, la conviction que toutes ces possessions sont justement et legitimement aux mains et sous la dependance de leurs detenteurs actuels. II presuppose, en outre si ceux qui, aux termes de cette proposition, doivent devenir les garants, ont la moindre prudence 1'examen des possibilites plus ou moins grandes degressions exterieures centre lesquelles ils sont appeles a se porter garants. Une agression de ce genre est plus ou moins probable, selon que les droits du posses-seur a garantir peuvent plus ou moins etre discutes par d'autres Etats ou d'autres peuples, ou sont plus ou moins susceptibles de faire 1'objet de rivalite entre eux.La Conference de la Paix n'a ni competence ni autorite pour faire une enquete sur la legitimite ou la justice de ces possessions, ou de formuler des conclusions a cet egard, pas plus, d'ailleurs, que suf la possibilite ou la probabilite qu'elles soient Covenant should be further amended so as to provide that the manufacture, by pri-vate enterprise, of munitions and implements of war, should be prohibited, and that in future, munitions and implements of"war should be manufactured by the Govern-ments concerned.Your Excellencv's advisers desire to express their approval of the principles embodied in the Covenant, subject to the amendments suggested in the Prime Mi-nister's memorandum, and to the further amendment herein proposed. This ap-proval is given on the assumption that it will be clearly understood by all the sigrta-tories to the Covenant that:i. The right of each nation to regulate and control the character of its ownpopulation by restriction of immigration is maintained unimpaired, !and thatsuch control is recognised as a matter of purely domestic concern, and not one in which the League of Nations is concerned;2. This Covenant does not in any way interfere with the fiscal freedom oiCanada, nor with the control or regulation of its own tariffs.The Committee of the Privy Council, on the recommendation of the Acting Secretary of State for External Affairs, advise that a copy hereof be forwarded to the Right Honourable the Prime Minister.All which is respectfully submitted.(Signed) RODOLPHE BOUDREAU, Clerk of the Privy Council.ARTICLE 10 OF THE COVENANT. - GUARANTEES AGAINST EXTERNAL AGGRESSION OF THE TERRITORIAL INTEGRITY OF ALL STATES MEMBERS OF THE LEAGUEMemorandum by the Right Honourable C. J. Doherty.This Article is open, in my judgment, to the very gravest objections, both generally, and from the point of view of countries in the condition and stage of development of Canada in particular.Of the gravity of the obligations by it imposed upon the parties to the Conven-tion, there can be no question. It makes of the League, as The Times expresses it, " a mutual guarantee society of unlimited liability. "(a) Generally. The clause makes each one of the nations signatories of the Convention the guarantor of the actual territorial possessions of all Members of the League, not only such as may be acquired under settlements effected in connec-tion with the Peace terms, but of all those held by them, at whatever time or in whatever manner acquired.That, as regards territory whose possession is allotted to any particular State by the Peace Treaty, those States which make the settlement and allot the territory should warrant peaceful possession to the allottee seems not unreasonable, if they consider it their duty or to their interest to do so.But why all the nations generally, including those taking no part in the deter-mination of conflicting claims to particular territories, should, as a condition of their membership in the League, undertake to give protection to the allottees, which may involve those so undertaking in all the horrors of wars in which they have no interest, in order to ensure respect for decisions in which they had no part and for which they have no responsibility, is not to me apparent.When one comes to consider the effect of the clause in respect to existing territorial possessions that is, the possessions of all the victorious belligerent and the neutral nations as they stood at the meeting of the Peace Conference, and whose delimitation or consideration formed no part of the work of the Peace Conference as such it is still more objectionable.The undertaking of such obligation with regard to these territories presup-poses a determination by those assuming it that all those existing possessions are rightly and justly in the hands and under the dominion of their present holders. It further presupposes, if those who, it is proposed, should become such guaran-tors are ordinarily prudent, some consideration of the greater or less likelihood of the occurrence of such external aggression as they are called upon to warrant against. Such aggression is more or less likely accordingly as the holding of the possessor to be guaranteed is more or less disputable by other States or peoples, or more or less liable to form the subject of contention between them.The Peace Conference has no jurisdiction or authority to inquire into or deter-mine the justice or legitimacy of the holdings in question, or the possibility or pro-bability of their being or becoming a bone of contention between disputing States ou puissent devenir un objet de contestation entre des Etats ou des peuples rivaux. Elle ne s'est livree a aucune enquete de ce genre, ni n'a pris aucune mesure pour se mettre a meme de formuler de telles conclusions. Et cependant, si elle adopte cet article, elle declarera en fait la legitimite de toutes ces possessions et elle imposera a toutes les nations desireuses de faire partie de la Societe, 1'obligation de garantir leur caractere definitif. En y consentant, ces dernieies se trouveront engagees a pro-teger ces possessions en cas degression, de menace ou de danger degression. Quant aux moyens par lesquels cette obligation pourra etre remplie, c'est au Conseil executif de la Societe qu'il appartient de formuler un avis, et d'apres cet avis, chaque nation sera appelee a participer a la garantie avec toutes les forces a sa dis-position.Manifestement, une decision aussi grave ne pourrait etre prise, et une obliga-tion aussi importante ne pourrait etre assumee, sans un examen approfondi cle toutes plaint.es ou objections auxquelles une possession existante, de ce genre, pourrait donner lieu. Ceci implique necessairement que Ton donne la possibilite de formuler une plainte ou une objection de ce genre, aux peuples ou aux Etats ayant participe ou non a la Conference qui peuvent avoir, ou croient avoir le droit cle les presenter. Meme si la Conference est prete a le faire, d'oii tire-t-elle le droit de se constituer juge des questions concernant les possessions territoriales appartenant a ses Membres ou a d'autres interesses, ou les revendications de possession, et le droit de trancher ces questions ? Elles ne lui ont, en effet, jamais ete deferees.Ses Membres n'ont jamais convenu que leurs possessions territoriales respectives pourraient etre soumises a une enquete, ou a une decision emanant. des autres Mem-bres, leurs collegues a la Conference. S'il existe des revendications contraires a ces possessions, soulevees par d'autres Etats ou peuples, ces derniers n'ont jamais soumis leurs droits au jugement de la Conference. N'en etant pas Membres, ils n'ont jamais eu 1'occasion de le faire et n'ont jamais ete mis en mesure de se faire entendre pour defendre leurs droits.N'etant pas autorisee a mettre en doute les questions de possessions territoria-les, la Conference n'a pas competence pour les juger. Une decision juridique de cette nature, si elle etait prise maintenant, mettrait la Conference et ses Membres parti-culierement les grandes Puissances - en mesure de profiter des circonstances ou les a places leur victoire, pour s'accorder reciproquement ratification de leurs titres de propriete, sans enquete, et pour obtenir une garautie universelle de ces titres, sans qu'aucun des interets adverses ait eu la possibilite de se faire entendre.Les nations membres de la Conference, les grandes Puissances en particu-lier sont-elles pretes a. ouvrir largement la porte 'k tous ceux qui ont a presenter des revendications, ou des preventions, contre la main-mise, par l'un quelconque , des Etats, sur les territoires qui relevent maintenant de leur souverainete ?Si elles ne sont pas pretes a le faire meme au cas oil la Conference serait competente - comment peut-on justifier la mesure proposee ? Comment une nation qui se respecte peut-elle preter la main a cette mesure, ou 1'appuyer ?Je sais bien que l'on a dit, pour justifier cette obligation absolue de protection reciproque des possessions existantes, qui a ete imposee, que les differends relatifs aux questions de territoires, ont ete une des sources de guerre les plus abondantes. Si cela est vrai, est-ce la une raison suffisante pour imposer a toutes les nations 1'obligation absolue de se ranger d'un seul cote, dans tous les differends de ce genre, et de soutenir ce cote avec force, simplement parce que c'est celui de la partie posse-dante ? Ne peut-on s'en remettre, pour empecher les guerres resultant de conflits territoriaux, aux dispositions prises pour empecher les guerres en general ? Pourquoi, dans ce cas particulier, la presomption de droit doit-elle etre exclusivement en faveur d'une partie, et pourquoi imposer le devoir d'epouser, dans chaque cas, la cause du possesseur, simplement parce qu'il est le possesseur ? Et cela, sans qu'il y ait au-cune procedure preliminaire quelconque pour's'assurer du bien-fonde de cette pos-session ! Pourquoi le droit a un territoire possede est-il tellement plus sacre que tout autre droit national, qu'il doive, a la suite d'un choix particulier, devenir non point 1'objet d'un interet national, mais celui d'un interet international universel; telle-ment plus sacre qu'une protection doive lui etre accordee qui ne s'etend point a tous les autres droits ?b) Objections pro fires au Canada et aux autres Dominions, ainsi qu'aux nations qui fiounaient se trouver dans des conditions analogues. - Meme si, malgre ce qui precede, il est juste d'accorder une garantie comme celle qui est proposee, ilnes'ensuit pas qu'elle doive 1'etre par tous les Etats. II peut etre juste qu'elle soit accordee par une certaine categorie cLEtats, mais il peut etre tout a fait injuste de Lexiger d'une autre. II existe de nombreuses raisons pour etablir une distinction de cette nature, et toutes sont propres a justifier le classement du Canada dans la categorie d'Etats a qui cette obligation onereuse ne devrait point etre imposee. Le Canada n'a pas voix au chapitre; il n'a aucune responsabilite dans tout reglement qui peut etre effectue par les Puissances a interets generaux, apres qu'elles ont entendu les Puissances a interets particuliers, directement interessees dans les questions, de territoires a attri-buer et clans les questions des Etats restaures ou nouvellement constitues avec des territoires possedes anterieurement par les Puissances vaincues. On ne peut done or peoples. It has made no such inquiry and taken no steps to place itself in a position to make such a determination. And yet, if it adopt this Article, it will in effect pronounce all these holdings to be right and impose upon all the nations which may enter the League the obligation of guaranteeing their permanency. By assen-ting to it, the latter will become bound to protect those possessions in case of aggres-sion, threat or danger of aggression. The means whereby that obligation will be fulfilled, the Executive Council of the League is to advise upon, and subject to that advice, each nation will be called upon to back the guarantee given by " the whole force at its disposal. "Clearly, so momentous a determination should not be made, and so grave an obligation should not be assumed, without careful consideration of any complaint or objection to which any such existing possession may give rise or be open. This necessarily implies giving opportunity for such complaint or objection being put forward by such States or peoples, whether parties to the Conference or not, as may have, or believe they have, a right to make them. Even if the Conference be prepared to do this, whence does it derive the right to constitute itself the judge of, and pass upon, questions affecting the territorial possessions, or claims to pos-sessions, of its members or others ? Those questions have never been submitted to it.Its members have never agreed to their respective territorial possessions becoming the subject of enquiry or determination by their fellow-members of the Conference. If there be adverse claims to any of these possessions on the part of other States or peoples, the latter have never submitted their rights to the adjudi-cation of the Conference. Not being members of it, they have never had any opportunity of doing so, nor any means of making themselves heard in defence of them.Without right to question, the Conference is without jurisdiction to pronounce upon these territorial possessions. Such a pronouncement, if now made, will put it and its members, more particularly the Great Powers, in the position of profiting by the circumstances in which their victory has placed them, to mutually give themselves a ratification of title without enquiry, and secure a world guarantee of that title without any possible adverse interest being heard.Are the nations members of the Conference the Great Powers in particular prepared to throw open its doors to all those who may have claims or pretensions to urge against the holding by any of the States of the territories over which they now exercise dominion ?If they are not even had the Conference jurisdiction how can the proposed action be justified ? Can a self-respecting nation be a party to or support it ?It has been, I understand, said as justifying the imposition of this absolute obligation of mutual protection of existing possessions that disputes with regard to territory are the most prolific sources of war. If this be true, is it a good reason for making it the absolute obligation of all nations to take the one side in every such dispute and to back up that side with force, merely because it is the side of the party in possession ? May not the prevention of wars resulting from disputes as to territories be left to the operation of the provisions made for the prevention of war generally ? Why, in this particular case, is right to be assumed to be on one side exclusively, and the duty imposed of espousing in every instance the cause of the possessor merely because he is the possessor and without any preli-minary proceeding of any kind to verify the justice, of that possession ? Why is right to possessed territory so much more sacred than any other national rights that it should be singled out to be made a matter of universal international, not a matter of national, concern, and a protection afforded to it which is not given to any other ?(b) Objections particular to Canada and other Dominions, and Nations whose conditions may be similar. Even if, notwithstanding what precedes, it is right that a guarantee such as proposed should be given, it does not follow that it should be given by all the States. It may be right that one class of States should give it, arid entirely wrong to exact it of another. Many reasons for such a distinction exist, and all of them justify Canada's being classed with those States upon which this onerous obligation should not be imposed. Canada has no say in, and no responsibility for, any settlement that may bemade by the Powers of general inte-rests, after hearing those of particular interests directly concerned therein, as to territory to be allotted to, or determined for, revived or newly created States, out of that formerly held by the vanquished Powers. There may be national aspirations to which the provisions of the Peace Treaty will not do justice and which cannot be permanently repressed. Subsequent Articles contemplate the possibility of war between two or more of the Signatories under such conditions that the other Signatories are not called upon to participate actively therein. If, as a result of such war, the nation attacked occupies and proposes to annex (possibly with the consent of a majority of the population) a portion of the territory of the aggressor, what is to be the operation of this Article ? Indeed, the Article seems inconsistent with the provisions of Articles 12 to i inclusive.. Obviously, a dispute as to territory is within the meaning and competence of the six Articles last referred to, under which a disposition of the dispute materially different from that proposed by Article 10 might be reached.
